chapter.summary: Covers the management of head injury in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with a head injury?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Ask about:
    • How and when the head injury occurred.
    • The mechanism of injury — a dangerous mechanism of injury or high-energy head injury is defined as:
      • Fall from a height of greater than 1 metre or 5 stairs.
      • High-speed motor vehicle collision either as a pedestrian, cyclist, or vehicle occupant.
      • Rollover motor accident or ejection from a motor vehicle.
      • Accident involving motorized recreational vehicles or bicycle collision.
      • Diving accident.
    • Current symptoms since the injury, such as:
      • Loss of consciousness.
      • Amnesia.
      • Vomiting.
      • Headache.
      • Neck pain.
    • Recent alcohol or drug intake.
    • Current anticoagulant medication.
    • Pre-injury level of consciousness and functioning.
  • Examine the person to assess:
    • The person's level of consciousness using the Glasgow Coma Scale.
    • For hypoxia or signs of shock (such as tachycardia, hypotension, reduced capillary refill time).
    • Signs of visible trauma to the scalp, skull, head, and neck.
    • Cranial nerves including pupil size and reactivity.
    • Any focal neurological deficit, such as:
      • Problems with visual or speech disturbance, understanding speech, reading or writing.
      • Problems with balance or walking.
      • Loss of muscle power.
      • Paraesthesia in the upper or lower limbs or abnormal reflexes.
    • For a suspected basal skull fracture, which may present with:
      • Clear fluid (possible cerebrospinal fluid) leaking from the ear(s) or nose.
      • Periorbital haematoma(s) with no associated damage around the eyes.
      • Bleeding from one or both ears; blood behind the ear drum (haemotympanum); new deafness in one or both ears.
      • Battle's sign — bruising behind one or both ears over the mastoid process, suggesting fracture of the middle cranial fossa.
    • For any neck tenderness — midline cervical spine tenderness may indicate cervical spine injury.
    • Range of neck movements — an inability to rotate the neck 45 degrees to the left and right may indicate cervical spine injury. Note: safe examination of the neck should only be performed using clinical judgement if the person:
      • Was involved in a simple rear-end motor vehicle collision.
      • Is comfortable in a sitting position.
      • Has been ambulatory at any time since the injury.
      • Has no midline cervical spine tenderness.
      • Presents with delayed onset neck pain.
  • Suspect non-accidental injury as a contributory factor or cause of head injury in a child if:
    • The child is not yet independently mobile (crawling, cruising, walking).
    • The injury or bruise is:
      • On any non-bony part of the face (including the eyes or ears).
      • On both sides of the face or head.
    • Any bruises are:
      • Disproportionate to the explanation of injury sustained.
      • Present in multiple sites or in clusters.
      • Of a similar shape and size.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Bruising.
    • The child has retinal haemorrhages or injury to the eye (in the absence of major confirmed accidental trauma or a known medical explanation).
    • The explanation for the injury is implausible, inadequate, or inconsistent:
      • With the child's presentation, normal activities, existing medical conditions, age or developmental stage, or account — compared with that given by parents or carers.
      • Between parents or carers.
      • Between accounts over time.
    • There is a delay in presentation.
    • For more information on when to suspect or consider physical abuse in children, see the CKS topic on Child maltreatment - recognition and management.

subChapters.htmlHeader: The Glasgow Coma Scale
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used internationally in clinical practice to assess the depth and duration of impaired consciousness and coma.

  • It is used to assess the level of consciousness in all people who have received a head injury (including people who appear intoxicated). People are scored on three different aspects of behavioural response: eye opening, verbal, and motor responses. Each response is evaluated independently of the other and graded, with the lowest possible score being 3 (deep coma or death), and the highest being 15 (fully awake).
    • For example, a person with a best score of 4 for eye response, 5 for verbal response, and 5 for motor response should be recorded as E4, V5, M5 and the total cumulative score of 14/15 given.
    • Note: people with dementia, chronic neurological disorders, or learning difficulties, for example, may have a pre-injury baseline GCS score of less than 15, which should be taken into account during clinical assessment.

Glasgow Coma Scale for adults and verbal children (usually 5 years of age and older).

  • Best eye response — does not open eyes, score 1; opens eyes in response to painful stimuli, score 2; opens eyes in response to voice, score 3; opens eyes spontaneously, score 4.
  • Best verbal response — makes no sounds, score 1; incomprehensible sounds, score 2; inappropriate words, score 3; confused and disorientated, score 4; orientated and converses normally, score 5.
  • Best motor response — makes no movement in response to pain, score 1; extension in response to painful stimuli, score 2; abnormal flexion in response to painful stimuli, score 3; flexion or withdrawal in response to painful stimuli, score 4; localizes painful stimuli, score 5; obeys simple commands, score 6.

Glasgow Coma Scale for preverbal children (usually less than 5 years of age).

  • Best eye response — no eye opening, score 1; eyes open in response to pain, score 2; eyes open in response to voice, score 3; eyes open spontaneously, score 4.
  • Best verbal response — no vocal response, score 1; inconsolable or agitated, score 2; inconsistently consolable or moaning, score 3; cries but is consolable or inappropriate interactions, score 4; smiles and orients to sounds, follows objects, and interacts, score 5.
  • Best motor response — no motor response to pain, score 1; extension in response to pain, score 2; flexion in response to pain, score 3; withdrawal from pain, score 4; localizing touch, score 5; spontaneous purposeful movement or obeys simple commands, score 6.
Severity of head injuryGlasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score
Mild13–15
Moderate9–12
Severe8 or less

[SIGN, 2009]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on how to assess a person with a head injury are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guidelines Head injury: assessment and early management [NICE, 2014c] and Child maltreatment: when to suspect maltreatment in under 18s [NICE, 2009], and the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) clinical guideline Early management of patients with a head injury [SIGN, 2009].

  • It is estimated that 25–30% of children aged under 2 years who are hospitalized with a head injury have a non-accidental injury [NICE, 2014c].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I follow up a person with persistent symptoms?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange to re-assess the person if they have ongoing symptoms or signs after a mild traumatic head injury.
    • Refer the person immediately to the hospital emergency department, to be accompanied by a competent adult, if there are persistent or worsening clinical features relating to the initial head injury, such as vomiting or headaches, which may indicate a possible complication.
    • If the person has other persistent non-specific post-concussion symptoms (such as mild intermittent headache, dizziness, generalized weakness, tinnitus, nausea, impaired cognitive function or memory, irritability, sleep disturbance, or fatigue):
      • Offer sources of support, information, and self-care advice.
      • Manage any symptoms appropriately, and reassure the person that symptoms are not usually serious, and normally resolve within 3 months of the injury. For more information on symptom management, see the CKS topics on Headache - assessment, Vertigo, Tinnitus, Insomnia, and Tiredness/fatigue in adults.
      • Manage pain and provide analgesia if needed. See the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues for more information.
      • Assess the impact of symptoms on daily activities, school, sports, work, driving, and relationships, and assess how any carers are coping with the person's needs. Be aware that the person may lack insight and awareness into any issues or difficulties they are having.
      • Advise the person to gradually return to normal activities, and encourage a regular schedule of activity and sleep. See the CKS topics on Tiredness/fatigue in adults and Insomnia for more information.
      • Ask about and manage any symptoms of anxiety, low mood, and flashbacks and nightmares, particularly if symptoms persist for more than three months. See the CKS topics on Generalized anxiety disorder, Depression, and Post-traumatic stress disorder for more information.
      • Assess for any issues with alcohol and drug misuse, and offer support as needed. See the CKS topics on Alcohol - problem drinking and Opioid dependence for more information.
    • Refer the person for specialist assessment and management of possible complications of a head injury to neurology or neuroendocrinology, neuropsychology or psychiatry, neurosurgery, or a specialist in rehabilitation medicine, depending on clinical judgement, if:
      • There are persistent non-specific symptoms for more than three months suggesting possible post-concussion syndrome.
      • Another complication or cause of head injury is suspected, for example, if there are new-onset focal neurological signs.
      • There are concerns or uncertainty about the nature or severity of symptoms.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on how to follow up a person with a head injury with ongoing symptoms and signs are based on the Scottish Intercollegiate Guideline Networks (SIGN) clinical guidelines Early management of patients with a head injury [SIGN, 2009] and Brain injury rehabilitation in adults [SIGN, 2013]; and expert opinion in review articles [Mott et al, 2012; Zaben et al, 2013].

Emergency referral to hospital if persistent symptoms
  • The SIGN guideline on brain injury rehabilitation states that delayed presentation of intracranial pathology is rare after mild traumatic brain injury, and usually occurs within 24 hours of the injury. A deterioration in clinical state 21 days after a head injury is very rare, occurring in only 0.1% of cases [SIGN, 2013].
  • The SIGN guideline on the early management of head injury recommends urgent reassessment of the person if there is a severe or increasing headache or persistent vomiting [SIGN, 2009].
Management of persistent non-specific symptoms
  • The SIGN guideline on brain injury rehabilitation recommends that uncomplicated symptoms should be treated the same as for the general population without a history of head injury [SIGN, 2013].
    • It notes that non-specific symptoms may be referred to as 'post-concussional syndrome', but states this is not a specific syndrome and is less likely to be secondary to neuronal damage, but may be caused by factors other than head injury, such as pain and distress [SIGN, 2013].
    • For people with prolonged symptoms following mild traumatic brain injury, personal and social factors may contribute to symptoms rather than the brain injury itself [SIGN, 2013].
  • The recommendation to offer reassurance and advice to people with persistent non-specific symptoms is based on the SIGN guideline on brain injury rehabilitation [SIGN, 2013] and expert opinion in a review article on subacute to chronic mild traumatic brain injury [Mott et al, 2012].
    • Early education about the diagnosis and symptoms of head injury and expected prognosis, can help to create realistic expectations, reduce anxiety, and help normalize symptoms [Mott et al, 2012].
    • This is supported by evidence from a placebo-controlled trial (n = 218) that showed that intervention in the form of reassurance and education given within the first few weeks of minor head injury significantly improved post-concussion symptoms, resulting in significantly less social disability (p = 0.01) and less severe post-concussion symptoms (p = 0.02) at follow up 6 months after injury in the active intervention group [Wade et al, 1998].
  • SIGN found that evidence consistently supports the fact that no cognitive deficits are typically attributable to mild traumatic brain injury beyond three months after injury, but if there is a complicated injury (for example, associated skull fracture), then significant cognitive deficits may result [SIGN, 2013].
  • The recommendation to manage pain is supported by the SIGN guideline on the early management of patients with a head injury, which states that agitation, restlessness, and aggression may be seen in the early stages of recovery from a head injury, and pain may be a cause (rather than a direct effect of any brain injury) [SIGN, 2009].
  • A gradual return to normal activities is recommended in a review article on subacute to chronic mild traumatic brain injury [Mott et al, 2012].
    • It notes that for people with persistent symptoms, it is important to address any co-morbidities or secondary problems that may complicate a person's recovery, such as stress, depression, or chronic pain [Mott et al, 2012].
  • SIGN highlights that a person should be assessed for anxiety, low mood, and flashbacks and nightmares if problems following a head injury persist for more than three months, as mood disorders and post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms may contribute to the 'overall burden of symptoms' in some people following mild traumatic brain injury. It suggests that referral for cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) following mild traumatic brain injury may be considered in people with persistent symptoms who have not responded to reassurance after three months [SIGN, 2013].
    • A US prospective cohort study of people during the first year after traumatic brain injury (n = 559) found that people who reported depression symptoms were more likely to have co-morbid anxiety, and depression was an independent predictor of reduced quality of life at one year follow up [Bombardier et al, 2010].
Referral for specialist assessment
  • The SIGN guideline on brain injury rehabilitation states for people with ongoing symptoms, referral to a multidisciplinary neuropsychological rehabilitation programme is recommended, to address any cognitive, emotional, and behavioural difficulties the person may be experiencing [SIGN, 2013].
    • For people with mild to moderate memory and cognitive impairment, 'external' aids such as diaries or electronic devices, and 'internal' strategies such as the use of visual imagery, can improve outcomes.
  • The recommendation to consider referral to neuroendocrinology if appropriate is based on expert opinion in a review article, to exclude complications of head injury such as hypopituitarism, which can present with non-specific symptoms and requires specialist investigation to confirm the diagnosis [Zaben et al, 2013].
  • The SIGN guideline notes that in a minority of people, head injury may be the result of a developing neurological condition, such as a brain tumour, which may cause loss of balance and predispose a person to falls. If there are persistent or new-onset focal neurological signs, for example, specialist referral to neurology should be arranged [SIGN, 2013].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I initially manage a person with a head injury?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Refer an adult or child immediately to the hospital emergency department, accompanied by a competent adult, if there are any of the following risk factors, which may indicate an intracranial complication or cervical spine injury: 
    • A Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of less than 15 on initial assessment.
    • Evidence of shock, or other injuries suggesting chest or abdominal trauma, limb or pelvic trauma, or significant vascular injury.
    • Dangerous mechanism of injury or high-energy head injury.
    • A history of bleeding or coagulation disorders, or current anticoagulant medication.
    • Current alcohol or drug intoxication.
    • Any loss of consciousness after the injury (even if they are fully alert on presentation).
    • Any post-traumatic seizure.
    • Any previous brain surgery.
    • Amnesia (antegrade or retrograde) lasting more than 5 minutes. Note: assessment of amnesia is unlikely to be possible in a child aged under 5 years.
    • Persistent headache since the injury.
    • Vomiting since the injury — particularly more than one episode in an adult or three or more episodes in a child, using clinical judgement.
    • Any focal neurological deficit since the injury.
    • A suspected open or depressed skull fracture, or tense fontanelle in a child.
    • A suspected basal skull fracture.
    • Signs of a penetrating injury or visible trauma to the scalp or skull — in children under 1 year of age, a bruise, swelling, or laceration of more than 5 cm on the head.
    • Suspected cervical spine injury following assessment of the neck.
    • Concern about the diagnosis of head injury.
  • Note: if there is any suspicion of cervical spine injury, full cervical spine immobilization should be arranged before transfer to hospital.
  • Refer an adult or child immediately to the hospital emergency department, accompanied by a competent adult, if there is:
    • Possible non-accidental injury, safeguarding concerns, or a vulnerable person is affected.
  • Consider referral of an adult or child to the hospital emergency department, accompanied by a competent adult, if there are any of the following risk factors, depending on clinical judgement:
    • Irritability or altered behaviour, particularly in infants and children aged under 5 years.
    • Other visible trauma to the scalp or skull.
    • A responsible adult is unable to stay with the person for the first 24 hours after the injury.
    • Ongoing concern by the person or their family/carers.
  • For all other children and adults who are at low risk of an intracranial complication or cervical spine injury:
    • Advise that a responsible adult should stay with the person for the first 24 hours after the injury.
    • Give the person and/or family/carers verbal and written information and self-care advice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on how to initially manage a person with a head injury and the risk factors for a serious complication are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Head injury: assessment and early management [NICE, 2014c] and the Scottish Intercollegiate Guideline Networks (SIGN) clinical guideline Early management of patients with a head injury [SIGN, 2009].

  • The risk of longterm complications of head injury may be increased if definitive treatment is delayed at presentation, so immediate transfer to the emergency department is essential if there are any risk factors for a possible intracranial complication or cervical spine injury [SIGN, 2009].
  • The risk factors identified for a suspected intracranial complication or cervical spine injury are specified by NICE as requiring consideration of a CT head or cervical spine scan (usually to be performed within 1 hour of the risk factor being identified) [NICE, 2014c].
  • The recommendation on the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is based on NICE which specifies that people with a head injury should have a CT head scan within 1 hour if their GCS score is less than 13 (less than 14 for children, or less than 15 for children under 1 year of age) on initial assessment in the emergency department, or less than 15 at 2 hours after the injury, or if they have other risk factors for skull fracture or other intracranial complication [NICE, 2014c].
  • The recommendation to assess vomiting since the injury using clinical judgement, reflects the high incidence of a single vomit in younger children with a head injury which alone is not necessarily a cause for concern [NICE, 2014c].
  • The recommendation to arrange hospital transfer for a person currently taking anticoagulant medication (such as warfarin), is a risk factor specified by NICE as requiring consideration of a CT head scan within 8 hours of the head injury [NICE, 2014c].
    • NICE acknowledges there was limited evidence identified for people using other anticoagulant and antiplatelet drugs regarding their need for an urgent CT head scan, as there is uncertainty as to whether they are at increased risk of intracranial haemorrhage [NICE, 2014c].
    • A prospective observational study highlights that early diagnosis of possible intracranial haemorrhage is important in order to start appropriate treatment, such as reversal of anticoagulation if appropriate, and/or neurosurgical intervention [Nishijima et al, 2012].
  • The recommendation to arrange hospital transfer for a person with amnesia is based on the fact that if there is some loss of consciousness or amnesia since the injury, some people will need a CT head scan within 8 hours, depending on the clinical presentation [NICE, 2014c].
    • The New Zealand Resuscitation Council highlights that clinicians should be aware that a person may have sustained a significant head injury without any loss of consciousness or amnesia, or any external signs of injury [ANZCOR guideline, 2016].
  • SIGN states that a reduced level of consciousness, loss of consciousness, focal neurology, and skull fracture are strong risk factors for an intracranial complication needing surgical intervention in children and adults [SIGN, 2009].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What information and self-care advice should I give?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Give verbal and written information and self-care advice to the person and/or family/carers following a head injury, including details of the nature and severity of the injury.
  • Give details of the expected recovery process and information on persistent, new, or delayed symptoms and signs which may indicate a possible complication, and when to immediately attend the hospital emergency department or seek urgent medical advice.
    • The Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) provides several advice leaflets including Advice for the person taking a patient home; Advice for a patient allowed home after a head injury; and Advice for carers of children who have sustained a head injury.
    • The charity Headway provides a factsheet Minor head injury discharge advice - Adults.
  • Give advice on a gradual return to normal activities, including school, work, sports, and driving.
    • The charity Headway provides an e-booklet Minor head injury and concussion, and factsheets Returning to education after brain injury and Returning to work after brain injury which may be helpful.
    • SIGN provides an advice leaflet Returning to sport after a head injury: a return to play protocol.
    • The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) document Assessing fitness to drive - a guide for medical professionals has information on whether a person is fit to drive following a head injury. This may be particularly important if there is evidence of transient global amnesia, behavioural disorders, or cognitive impairment following a head injury, for example.
    • The charity Headway has an information leaflet Driving after brain injury which may be helpful.
  • Give advice on additional sources of support and information, such as:
    • Brain and Spine Foundation (www.brainandspine.org.uk) which funds research, education, and information programmes aimed at improving the prevention, treatment, and care of people affected by disorders of the brain and spine. It has a telephone helpline 0808 8081000.
    • Child Brain Injury Trust (www.childbraininjurytrust.org.uk) which supports children, young people, and families affected by an acquired brain injury. It has a telephone helpline 0845 6014939.
    • Headway — The Brain Injury Association (www.headway.org.uk) is a charity which supports people affected by a head injury. It runs a telephone helpline 0808 8002244 and a network of local support groups and offers rehabilitation programmes, carer support, community outreach, and respite care. It has a range of factsheets and e-booklets for patients and healthcare professionals, including Caring for someone with a brain injury; The effects of brain injury and how to help, and Parenting after brain injury.
    • SIGN has a booklet for patients and carers Brain injury rehabilitation in adults.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
This information is largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Head injury: assessment and early management [NICE, 2014c]; the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) clinical guidelines Early management of patients with a head injury [SIGN, 2009] and Brain injury rehabilitation in adults [SIGN, 2013]; the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) document Assessing fitness to drive - a guide for medical professionals [DVLA, 2016]; and expert opinion in a review article on subacute to chronic mild traumatic brain injury [Mott et al, 2012].

  • The SIGN guideline on early management of patients with a head injury notes that the risk of rapid deterioration is higher during the first six hours and reduces as the time since the head injury increases [SIGN, 2009].
  • Early education about the diagnosis and symptoms of head injury and expected prognosis, can help to create realistic expectations, reduce anxiety, and help normalize symptoms [Mott et al, 2012].
